title.value: Categorical Generative Model Evaluation via Synthetic Distribution Coarsening
title.justification: The title is clearly stated at the beginning of the document and in headers throughout the paper.
title.quote: Categorical Generative Model Evaluation via Synthetic Distribution Coarsening

extractions.description: The paper proposes a novel evaluation method for generative models focusing on nominal categorical data. It introduces a synthetic data setting to return where the ground truth is known, emphasizing probabilistic guarantees and sample complexities. The method involves coarsening high-dimensional probability spaces to smaller spaces, allowing for meaningful statistical estimates.

type.justification: The paper focuses on proposing a theoretical framework and methodology for evaluating generative models using synthetic distribution coarsening.
type.quote: Our key contribution is the development of a novel procedure for evaluating (multivariate) categorical generative models on synthetic data that 1) is designed for the realistic large sample space setting (on the order of billions of elements); 2) provides statistical guarantees; 3) is robust to different patterns of mismatch between p, q; and 4) offers interpretable results.

name.justification: The paper is focused primarily on evaluating generative models, particularly in handling categorical data.
name.quote: We propose a procedure for constructing a ground truth distribution that retains key real-world dataset characteristics and illustrate how this synthetic distribution can be used to meaningfully rank four recent categorical generative models.

name.justification: The paper introduces a synthetic data setting for evaluation of generative models where the ground truth distribution is known.
name.quote: We propose to take an alternative approach and to return to the synthetic data setting where the ground truth is known.

name.justification: The paper focuses on evaluating generative models dealing with categorical data.
name.quote: We focus on nominal categorical data and introduce an evaluation method that can scale to the high-dimensional settings often encountered in practice.

name.justification: The entire method revolves around manipulating probability spaces to evaluate generative models.
name.quote: Our method involves successively binning the large space to obtain smaller probability spaces and coarser distributions where meaningful statistical estimates can be obtained.

name.justification: The CNF model is identified as a categorically specialized flow model known in the literature.
name.quote: CNF Lippe and Gavves (2021), a normalizing flow method with a learned mapping to the categorical space

is_contributed.justification: The paper references CNF as a model used for comparison, not as a contribution from the authors.
is_contributed.quote: We select four SOTA generative categorical models: 1) CNF Lippe and Gavves (2021)...

is_executed.justification: The paper includes CNF in empirical tests to compare its performance with other models.
is_executed.quote: Next we show how our procedure ranks existing generative models for the SEQUENCE experiments.

is_compared.justification: CNF is specifically compared against other models in the paper's results section.
is_compared.quote: In contrast, our metric provides a ranking that is consistent with the ranking provided by the total variation estimate over the whole space.

referenced_paper_title.value: Categorical Normalizing Flows via Continuous Transformations
referenced_paper_title.justification: The CNF model is referenced from Lippe and Gavves (2021), which is cited in the paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: CNF Lippe and Gavves (2021), a normalizing flow method with a learned mapping to the categorical space
